Definition: Determine whether or not the given comment is Obscene. Any depiction or description of sexual topics that offends moral principles is referred to as obscenity.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Guess Barron needs to babysit the dummy and supervise his tweets.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Shut up nerd. You try too hard.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic but is not obscene.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Sailors found whores and coke.I'm shocked!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: The Bechdal test?  Seriously?   I couldn't help but admire this movie for its agentful female protagonist.  She demonstrates mettle and fortitude throughout the entire movie; she displays constant resistance to an infantilizing and sexually imposing predator, and, finally, the choice she makes in the final scene while listening to the radio (no spoiler, I hope).  Not to mention some serious badassary (sp?)!   There are cliches no doubt: a line or two like "You've got to be kidding me," a sophisticate and a country bumpkin bond, and when the violence gets going some impossibly close calls, but cliches are sort of requisite in thrillers.  What we didn't see in this movie, and we normally expect from this genre, is an exploitation of women and their bodies, an agentless female with, at best, a trick or two up her sleeve, or even--and holy crap!--any sex at all.  Awesome movie, which one did you watch?

Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton. 
There's nothing unconstitutional about a prosecutor working an investigation finding evidence of other, related or even unrelated crimes. And of course, it's constitutional to pursue those other crimes. 
Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees.  It was the legislature, school boards, city and county governments, et al who chose to NOT pay the contribution as it was "credited" to employee retirement accounts.... This, as we're seeing today, was a MASSIVE mistake. Gary Crum

Comment: Everything about the Trump Presidency is laid back blase BS. There is one of 3 possibilities I personally see by playing the Presidency fast and loose like this:

1. Something will bite trump in the ass that will highly embarrass him, and he will sober up to the fact that he needs to take this job serious. (That is the best case scenario.) 

2. Something will bite Trump in the ass and result in something hurting the US on an international level, and result in fallout on the international level. Take your pick what this is? NK invading SK for some reason. Trump pulling out of NATO resulting in Russia invading someone somewhere due to the chaos that ensues, etc.

3. Something that trump does in the US will cause a cascade effect at home. I can't claim to know what that would be, because its far too early in his presidency. Economy, race relations, etc. Its too soon to feel the fallout of climate change. Who knows.

But I can guarantee you one of those things is going to happen.

Comment: Outsider:  It's tough to rewrite history, but I'll give you credit for trying.  The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

Comment: "I recall in the Sixties ..."  which means, Andrew, you probably remember a time when "women professionals" was an oxymoron.  Me, too...and I distinctly recall the first female announcer and first female newscaster hired by the station in the mid-1970s.   See?  Definite progress, no?

Broadcasting? A profession? "Not the same," doctors, dentists and lawyers might sniff.  Well, many of us did consider it so.  An 8-hour day?  Maybe the morning show guy (who got up at 4:45 to be on the air at 6.) Even he did Saturday remotes.  After a five-day week, I'd roll in for 3-4 hours on a Saturday morning, too, to learn more about my craft from a Vancouver writer who came in part-time.  Man, did I learn.  No extra dough, either.  Just...priceless lessons.  Stayed until 6:30 many nights. The production studios were empty and I could record, edit, play around, discover what was possible... 

Maybe there was one difference from, say, the legal firm.  I had FUN, every single damn day.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: The Legislature fiddles while the state burns.

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: "Lies, damned lies, and statistics" is a phrase describing the persuasive power of numbers, particularly the use of statistics to bolster weak arguments. It is also sometimes colloquially used to doubt statistics used to prove an opponent's point. Wikipedia Reference to Mark Twain's dubious attribution of this to Benjamin Disraeli.

I read the research mentioned and I would cite the following:
-The sample size in this study allows the authors to come to the conclusion they want to come to in the first place
-Oregon Live has an article on the worst Oregon wildfires, http://www.oregonlive.com/wildfires/index.ssf/2017/09/the_worst_wildfires_in_oregon.html
-Of these, half are brush fires
-The others are forest fires. All were in old growth or reburns of previous fires that did not get salvaged
-The Elliot Forest, became state ownership after the original old growth was burnt around 1880.
-The B&B Complex, Whitewater Fire, Eagle Creek, Strawberry Wilderness, all unmanaged lands

Comment: Hello Gadabout1,

You seem a lot more convinced this is pure good news than do the newspaper editors!

If you had been paying attention to this page over the past few hours, you would have noticed that the reporting and emphasis have actually zig zagged back and forth, in editorial modifications, from this as good news (many months in a row of job increases) to this as bad news (much worse job figure than previous month, low number created compared to previous months, bad recent trajectory) and then back again to this as good news.

What that reporting oscillation means is that the editors recognize that the glass is half full and half empty with the recent month's numbers, and viewers (and editors, in a vacillating fashion hour-to-hour) are able to emphasize either side.

You are welcome, nonetheless, to pretend it is a binary matter in a simple binary world, if you prefer.

Comment: Good coverage of a very important issue....loss of private property rights. Thanks for reporting this. And many thanks to the people who pushed to retain and exercise their rights. Ownership of real property is not necessarily such a nice thing as the real estate, lenders, and related businesses would have us believe. Often, a simple owner of a single property, is abused by neighbors whose trees overhang, but who refuse to trim, or whose dogs break a common boundary fence but refuse to repair or replace, or in the case of  Marco Polo situation, are simply victims of a horrible disaster due to circumstances well beyond their control. Other countries have better schemes for residential property ownership and management which may not always be the single sole owner, but some form of ownership whereby the resident has protections enforced by government. What do elderly owners do in situations like this? Just suffer it out until they die? We have a cruel world here. Thanks for highlighting.

Comment: I come from BC and have lived through several resource cycles in my 40 years of home ownership.  I agree with most of what you say.  Typical real estate behaviour in these cycles is a continual downward pressure, first as the resource sector flounders, then second as the EI and savings runs out.  

As you suggested, we are between those stages  now; so we can expect a slight levelling off, then another strong surge downwards as people are forced to sell against their will.
This second downward surge is generally followed by a decade of neutral pricing and stagnant sales until demand and supply even out.  

I would be looking at a decade before I considered buying for investment purposes.

Comment: How does it "defy reality", John? Please clarify rather than making a general statement of dismissal... unless, of course, you can't back up that statement.

It is a lie- yes, outright lie- to say the CPAs were only about the Mercer Slough. Comment: The authors say “the bank still doesn’t publish minutes of the council’s rate-decision meetings, as many other major central banks do”; it is much worse than this. The Bank of Canada doesn’t even state after a meeting which members of the Governing Council had voted to move the overnight rate up, down or keep it unchanged. The C.D. Howe Institute’s Monetary Policy Council has meetings in advance of the interest rate announcements of the Bank of Canada. Minutes of these meetings aren’t published either, in the sense of detailed summaries of who said what as opposed to a general summary of the tenor of the debate. However, it is recorded how each member voted on interest rate changes for the given month and for a year ahead. Surely Canadians should also know how the Governing Council voted on changes in the overnight rate for the month in question.

Comment: The law of unintended consequences at work here ... people move to
urban settings because of the 'cool' factor ... costs increase ... cool 
decamps, or simply dissapears. 

For a while small businesses persist ... because of leases or hope ... 
suddenly the market crashes. The consequence ... shuttered storefronts.

The cumulative burden of taxes is killing businesses. Every tax increase 
cascades down upon small businesses. Which of course decreases demand
for the goods they sell. Which reverberates throughout the market place.

Slackening of demand causes wholesalers to close their operations. And of
course this has the knock on effect of reducing tax receipts. Bureaucratic
spending aggregates. No single cost increase seems like much. It is the 
aggregate of all the costs cascading down which eventually reverberates 
up. 

Travellers in the U.S. surely notice these effects. Shuttered main streets 
was the beginning. Now the suburban stores are shuttering — bankrupt.

So why are you against them?

Comment: Representative Tuck is clearly misinformed:

The Real ID Act, 119 Stat. 312, Section 201 (3) reads:
"The term ‘‘official purpose’’ includes but is not limited to accessing Federal facilities, boarding federally regulated   commercial   aircraft,   entering   nuclear   powerplants,  and  any  other  purposes  that  the  Secretary  shall  deter-
mine.
(4) SECRETARY.—The term ‘‘Secretary’’ means the Secretary of Homeland Security."

Therefore, there is a legal obligation for identification checks to board aircraft subject to TSA screening, and the section explicitly states that it can be required to enter federal facilities, which includes DOD installations.
This is not language from DHS, this is language from the law passed by Congress. It's available directly from the Government Publishing Office for free as a PDF.

Comment: LRT is not outdated now, but in twenty or thirty years when ridership might finally allow the investment to make sense (for then, not the prior years) it will be outdated. Driverless buses based on software updated monthly (or tweaked daily, like many large software systems) will for that reason always be up-to-date. Because a hundred million people could be using the same system, it will be very well designed. A fleet of nimble buses could be programmed for point-to-point service, i.e. neighbourhood-to-station. There is a reason our streets have evolved to be how they are; they allow extreme flexibility for door-to-destination service.

Comment: It is folly to compare Donald Trump or anyone else to Jay Hammond, as each is as unique as the time they -& we, are experiencing. The least we can do is to watch, then either civilly resist or support President Trump as he deals with the problems at hand. 

In their individual ways, both are/were reluctant politicians, but have put on the gloves, taken up the sword, because they perceive a need for action. Both sacrificed personal time and interests for the good of the state or country. 

Our Founding Fathers also made enormous personal sacrifices for the good of the country.  

To best recognize and honor the action of our forebears, we should all actively participate in the processes of the Republic with which we have been so blessed. Motives of participants in government should be beyond personal gain. Public service should be at personal sacrifice, not for personal gain.

Comment: Peter:

I appreciate your thoughtful comments. If you read closely, you'll note I make no defense of the erection of statues or the premise of "states' rights,' though I am a Federalist and recognize the vast differences about how people in the 19th Century felt about states as opposed to now. My point is that individual liberty allows for context, differences of opinion, and deliberation. I'm not opposed to local communities or elected officials making a decision to move these monuments. What I do reject is the notion that our leaders should make these decisions based on trying to satiate a majoritarian mob. Conservatives (classical Liberals) are absolutely for freedom, liberty and justice for all peoples; but that is not achieved through lawless behavior. 

Our ultimate goal of freedom, liberty and justice for all is best achieved through economic freedom and human flourishing. Such freedom recognizes no color or country or origin. Focusing on identity is counter to our goal.

Thanks

Comment: That's right. Just goes to show that an errant comma can confuse readers. There is no need for the comma in the following sentence: "The budget is $6.5 million, or two-tenths of 1 percent higher than the preliminary spending plan for state agencies offered by Gov. Bill Walker."

However, if the writer does want to set off the comparison with a comma, then the appositive structure should be enclosed by commas on both sides.  Either way works. The single comma has confused jimb.

This works: The budget is $6.5 million, or two-tenths of 1 percent, higher than the preliminary spending plan for state agencies offered by Gov. Bill Walker.  

But I prefer no commas: The budget is $6.5 million or two-tenths of 1 percent higher than the preliminary spending plan for state agencies offered by Gov. Bill Walker.

Comment: Alaskan, you don't have all the facts. There are many parts of Chugach State Park where the odds of running into a brown bear are far less than in the section of Bicentennial Park where bear use is concentrated for reasons I mentioned in the article. 

Generally speaking, building a popular bike trail near a salmon-spawning stream is a bad idea in bear country.  Bicentennial Park is bear country.  The South Fork of Campbell Creek is one of the most productive salmon-spawning streams in the Anchorage area. The two advanced downhill singletrack trails that are of most concern are far enough from the creek that I wouldn't normally object; however, as I mentioned, bear use is concentrated in this area by the two subdivisions on either side of the park and by the higher activity levels near Hilltop Ski Area.

Comment: Actually, the state's balanced budget amendment is what prevents a state deficit, not TABOR.  

We have an issue that people have a deep emotional investment in and they barely understand.  There's a lot more to TABOR than simply requiring votes on tax increases.  It also mandates refunds if state revenue growth exceeds inflation (with some adjustment for population growth).  That means state revenues  don't reflect economic growth, which creates a problem because economic growth impacts infrastructure.  But we don't get to talk about those repercussions because people don't understand what TABOR actually does.  So we get "tax and spend liberals bankrupting the state!" instead of actually debates over economic policy.

Comment: I moved to Alaska in 1972.  In 1972, Alaska state government revenue was $365 million and expenditures were $372 million.  In 1969 those numbers were $198 million in revenue and $212 million in expenditures so between 1969 and 1972 oil money was already making a big difference in both revenue and expenditures.  

Adjusting for inflation, $365 million in 1972 dollars is equal to $2,127 million in 2016 dollars - a bit over $2 billion dollars.  However, according to the article, the State of Alaska is now spending $5.5 billion or about 2.5 times as much as it did in 1972 but it is receiving less revenue than it did in 1972.  

The Permanent Fund is unique in American government.  If you dip into it now, instead of reducing the size of government back to about $2 billion, when will you stop?

Comment: TNR and releasing domesticated animals into the wild are two different things, as is managing a feral cat colony. Releasing domesticated animals into the wild is a bad idea, and this animal rescue group should not be advocating for that. Feeding feral cat colonies is also a bad idea in many cases. However, TNR should not be lumped in with those activities. TNR only involves fixing the cats that are already in the wild population, so that they don't breed. Those cats are already out there. TNR just insures they aren't reproducing. Very different from feeding the colony or introducing pets into the wild.

Comment: Because of existing federal legislation, marijuana businesses cannot open a bank account, nor use checking accounts.  The rule is "cash only".  In today's business environment, federal payroll taxes must be deposited online via EFT sites which require bank accounts.  This is an example of one challenge these dispensaries are facing in the battle to become fully operational.  These types of barriers tend to make operating costs exhorbitantly high for marijuana-related ventures.  Change must somehow be made at the federal level, or medical marijuana production and distribution will never be legitimized.  The underground will continue to operate and flourish, generally to the detriment of probably a majority of medical users who are and will be unable to propagate and cultivate the plant for their own medicinal use.

Comment: I believe that homelessness is an issue that needs to be addressed, but there is a big difference between the "homeless" and "Travelers".  "Homeless" to me means that a person is in need and wants to do better for themselves and family. The true "homeless" are the people who try to better their situation by taking ownership and putting in effort. Because you see someone on the corner does not mean they are "homeless", it's just their choice to get money. It is a fact that some "homeless" do not what to better themselves, that is on them, not me for take care of. 

"Travelers" to me are people that are "traveling" and have stopped to get what they can before traveling on. Many travelers are young and are part of the "gimmie" generation and do not care of the community they are in, or the people that live here. They just get all then can and then leave to get more from somewhere else.

So, let break from lumping the "homeless" and "Travelers" together, they are not one and the same.

Comment: That is a strange and troubling headline.

"Supreme Court urged to clarify law on journalist source protection".

Hello?

No, it is not properly the job of the Supreme Court to "clarify law".

Law is written by a different branch of government, the legislative branch. THAT branch of government ought to ensure laws are written with sufficient clarity.

Look, if a journalist wants to challenge the constitutionality of a law on the books, that is fine and terrific, they ought properly do as is being done: Challenge the law in court with a lawyer, and argue that the law over-reaches and violates a fundamental right in the Charter. 

If the learned judges of the court agree, terrific, the law will be overturned as unconstitutional.

But for crying out loud, that is not the Supreme Court "clarifying law". 

Instead , it is the Supreme Court rejecting a law as unconstitutional.

They are not the same acts. Use "SETTLE", not "clarify".

Clarifying law belongs back at the legislative stages.

Comment: "It doesn't fix the problem" is different from "just another source of revenue." 

Of course red light cameras won't fix everything - Toronto needs to look at a wholesale redesign of many of its streets to reduce speeds and change driver behaviour. But in the meantime, I don't have any problem collecting revenue from drivers who think they can drive through red lights. Don't want to give money to the government? Stop at red lights. 

But let's come back to that "it doesn't fix the problem" claim: According to the article you linked to, that's not clear. Yes, some collisions are up, but "Accidents involving pedestrians, bicyclists and other "non-motorists" were down 19.64 percent.". 

A further study found that cities that turned off their red light cameras saw a 30% increase in fatalities: http://www.iihs.org/iihs/news/desktopnews/turning-off-red-light-cameras-costs-lives-new-research-shows

Comment: It isn't the capping of the MID that is going to affect most people, it's the "relabeling" of the personal exemption as a part of the "standard deduction". Comment: As I understand it, the current situation is this:
1 A Hawaii citizen has a registered firearm
2 This person is convicted of a felony in another state
3 The person returns to Hawaii
4 There is no system in place to inform HPD that the person should no longer have access to a firearm.
5 The person tries to register a new firearm
6 HPD finds out the person should not have any firearms, and requires the individual to give up his firearms

It seems to me that this problem should be solved at the federal level with this change in operations:
1 A Hawaii citizen has a registered firearm
2 This person is convicted of a felony in another state
3 The operators of the federal database inform HPD that person should no longer have a firearm
4 HPD requires the individual to give up his firearms upon their return to Hawaii

It is most likely that I'm completely misreading the situation, law, capabilities of the federal database, or a bunch of other factors. Can someone clear this up for me?

Comment: Perhaps the county could consider an animal control program that mirrors the FireMed program. Ask all households to pay a small voluntary basic annual fee to cover their dogs against the possibility of being picked up by animal control, which requires a steep fine to get the dog back. No one may sell or gift a dog without an RFID implant. Veterinarians may not treat a dog without an RFID. Any dog found loose without an RFID will not be held for more than 1 week before risking being sold or euthanized. Offer the RFID at minimal cost through the county, about $25, and free registry through the county or at https://www.freepetchipregistry.com/. People may tend to abandon their dog rather than pay the fine if not covered by the annual fee, but their next dog will have to have an RFID when they obtain it, and abandonment of an RFID'd dog will not get you out of the fine, so most people will eventually wise up and pay the annual fee. Comment: There are two guys off the market that would have been fits for Toronto, positionally.  That is Cespedes and Beltran.  Everyone else is still available.  The thing that this article presumes is that if Rogers simply opens their wallets players will come here.  This isn't like going to the grocery store and buying what you want. In this case, the groceries have a say in who buys them.

Let's take a guy I'd like the Jays to open up their wallets for:  Dexter Fowler.  He'd be a perfect fit on this team.  Suggestions are that he's looking for something in the 4-5 year range at $18M per year.  Let's say Toronto offers him 5 years and his requested $18M per year.  Does Dexter Fowler WANT to play in Toronto, where he likely won't play centre field?  If another team with a CF opening offers him the same, he likely goes there.  The Jays would then have to overpay for Fowler to even consider coming to Toronto, and even then there's no guarantee that he chooses playing in a corner OF spot.

Comment: There was not any printing press in the Second Century.  The Liturgy was adopted to the area [province] where the people WERE Christian and celebrated.  There certainly wasn't any Liturgical 'watch-dog' group over-seeing developments in the liturgy.  This was done, not only in Greek, but in other languages in which the Liturgy was celebrated.  At this time, there was no Eastern and Western Churches.  For example, in the Chaldean and  Assyrian Rites, there are no words of Institution of the Eucharist, no consecration.  This went on for centuries [yes, they were and are faithful Catholics].  It was acknowledged with an agreement only on October 26, 2001.  There were other places during the Liturgies, where there is reference to the words of Jesus.

When the Benedictine Order was established, the monks undertook the task of printing by hand---Sacred Scripture and the Liturgy.  But there were mistakes as well in the hand printing.  When humans do anything, there are errors.

Comment: Paul Krugman's argument for 400 trillion in direct stimulus was justified, and it likely would have brought down the debt by generating jobs, more consumer purchases, and more revenues.  In addition, the proposed infrastructure jobs needed (and still need) doing, and the work itself would represent an investment with long-duration returns.  Deficits now run up the debt, and an unstimulated economy produces lower wages and lower return on private investment.  Deficits are caused by inadequate revenue to meet budget needs, and their cure is direct economic stimulation.  The 400 trillion was based mostly on the amount of money that disappeared with the financial collapse of 2008. which took the economy down with it.

Debt itself isn't bad; in fact, without debt, our modern economy just wouldn't work at any level.  Debt is cheap with our practically zero interest rates; and a little more inflation would help to shrink the debt.

Comment: This "historial [sic] note" is a gross distortion of history, in fact, just the sort of thing that Stephen Miller and his alt-right ilk like to put out there by way of rattling the republic.

The pedestal of the Statue of Liberty was always understood to be the US contribution to the monument, along with the federally owned island in NY  Harbor which sculptor Frédéric Bertholdi liked as his ideal site. The poem by Emma Lazarus, as epigram for that pedestal, was part of the fund-raising effort from early on.

Yes, neither the poem nor the statue is "policy," strictly. But the statue commemorates both liberation from the UK and the emancipation of slaves, as the essential US message to the world: so it's policy in a more general way. And the poem's extended interpretation of Liberty as the one who shelters and comforts the afflicted victims of injustice throughout the world has long struck Americans as quite natural. To say now that the poem is insignificant is absurd and perverse.

Comment: Here's my explanation.  

Once you make pot available at the corner drug store--which, incidentally, still can't sell booze--you make it socially acceptable. Not "prevalent" or even "allowable" but ACCEPTABLE. There are millions of Canadians who don't indulge today because pot still carries a stigma, even fear. You erase the stigma and fear through legalization and watch the market INCREASE. Why do you think Shoppers wants in? Yeah, sure, it's "medicinal."  So was the booze pharmacies once sold with a doctor's prescription. Pardon my scepticism.

Pot on the roads today?  Sure.  But nothing like it'll likely be once it's legal and the stigma is gone.  "Must be safe...It's legal, right?"  

"Also, would you start taking heroin if it was legalized tomorrow? No? Nor would most, I suspect." You're right. I wouldn't. That's for sure.  Most? Maybe not. But more and more people likely would.  No-risk, legally, right?  No law-and-order consequences. So, you're OK legalizing this.  No? Howcum?

Comment: Many UA faculty and staff are not automatically opposed to SP. I, for one, was persuaded early on by some of the ideas in SP and eagerly volunteered to serve on one of the committees. But like many of my colleagues, I am now dismayed by the decision-making process that leaves key people shut out. For example, in the School/College of Education decision reversal, even the Chancellor and Provost at UAF did not know that the decision had been reversed. To date, SP has not provided data to demonstrate the utility of decisions in cutting costs or improving education. Little to no impact analysis has been done. I'm not saying that Abel's plan is perfect, but it does at least attempt to project cost savings and possibilities for generating new sources of revenue. Ideally, SP could be strengthened by some of the New Vision ideas so that we have a synthesis approach.

In summary, you're saving comparatively few jobs and increasing price pressure tremendously.

Comment: It seems like there's a little bit of passing the buck here.   Ferguson is finishing up his 10 year term.    If mistakes highlighted in an audit were NOT fixed, and the follow up audit found "deja vu all over again", then the AG has the power to go public with this and highlight the failings.    It shouldn't happen a third time.   

With regard to the silo problem, that's what happens when different Ministries are competing for budgets.    It happens in the private sector too, (inter-divisional) but is caught sooner.       

There needs to be some "best practices" guidelines that are common across departments and there should also be incentives for departments to adopt or develop "best practices".    In  Public Sector setting, the problem is, budgets are protected like gold and there are no real incentives to do things more efficiently.    In fact, at the end of a budget cycle, it's common for departments with leftover budgets to go on a spending spree to use it.

Comment: Screening mammograms every 2 or 3 years, or even yearly, are no guarantee that breast cancer will be detected. After my GP ruled out breast cancer when I displayed what I later learned was a symptom ("nothing to be concerned about"), my breast cancer (Lobular) was not discovered until a year later, when I was finally sent for a diagnostic and ultrasound. Diagnosis: stage 3 (T7 N14 M0). 
The cancer had been there for at least 3 - 5 years when it was discovered, and I had been having yearly screening mammograms throughout that time. Educating women about the symptoms of breast cancer rather than relying solely on screening mammograms is essential, as is a healthy disrespect for GPs when the patient senses that something is not right.  I learned the hard way.

Comment: No one said we shouldn't have roads. 
Just that we should prioritize pedestrians, transit, and biking above private cars in funding and design of our public space. 
Currently we prioritize car traffic far above all else, making all other means of getting around extremely difficult. 
Continuing to do this is not sustainable. There is not and will never be enough money and space for everyone to drive. We have to invest our limited transportation funds in modes that are more energy and space efficient, and that are financially sustainable. That means putting money into bike and pedestrian infrastructure. That means not only allowing buses to use the roads, but dedicating them space so that they can function efficiently and actually be useful to people. 

I did not say to build special roads for commercial vehicles. I was placing them within a hierarchy of priorities, and suggesting that the gas tax they pay needs to be raised.

Comment: (CONTINUED FROM ABOVE):

(4) And perhaps most importantly in the context of this discussion, F. catus kills on reflex at the sight of movement regardless of hunger--it's killing and feeding reflexes are controlled by separate regions of its little brain.  We bred them that way.  Wild cats don't do that.  They kill for hunger, to feed their young and to teach them to hunt.

(5) Fluffy doesn't control rodents, she ATTRACTS 'em.  She and her little mousey playmates trade T. gondii oocysts back and forth like poker chips.  When she kills and eats a bit of them, the parasites return to her digestive tract to reproduce and the cycle is complete.  And T. gondii eats your brain.  Among other things.

(6) Evidence for the above is that Australia has been overrun with feral cats for better than a century and overrun with MICE just as long.  In fact by destroying native rodents cats facilitate the spread of invasive pest rodent species.  80-90% of Australian feral cats are infected with toxo.

Comment: Keep in mind, PERS was “reformed” already and it happened years ago: anyone hired in late 2003 or after gets a meager and limited amount.

There wasn't fiscal responsibility before PERS was “refomed.” The state wasn't willing to pay competitive wages, so they put extra money into retirement (which is cheaper for the taxpayers, actually). It was a good fiscal decision. 

This “reform” which has to lead to increased wages is actually a worse deal for taxpayers – again, paying higher wages costs taxpayers more than funding retirement. 

There's a bunch of distortion being sold in this piece-of-crap "reporting." It buries the reality, such as this line:

"The top beneficiaries are the outliers in the PERS system. The average annual system-wide annual benefit is $29,721 a year; the median is $23,500 annually." 

These types of stories are written for the express purpose of manipulating people into outrage. Don’t fall for it.

Comment: No government is a threat to everyone. I should mention the libertarian paradise, Somalia. Ah, fair Somalia, where there is no government to interfere with the individual.

Libertarians will claim that Somalia has nothing to do with libertarianism, and linking the two is a sore point with them. They claim that it isn't true libertarianism, it's anarchy. True libertarians believe in just enough government to protect private property and personal safety; without those protections, they argue, anarchy ensues. The problem is that they cannot point to even one current or historical example of a government that functions as they imagine it should. They have no real world examples, so they ply their arguments as a theoretical construct.

Every example of places with little centralized government is dismissed by libertarians as an anarchistic situation, not a "true" libertarianism. It's the "no true Scotman" fallacy, Ron Paul edition.

Comment: The Elwha River has been busy rebuilding riverbanks and gravel bars and has creating some 70 acres of new beach and riverside estuary habitat for Dungeness crabs, forage fish, clams, and other species. Comment: Where to even start. Your comment assumes some deference to the two-party framework, and yet a majority of us Coloradans are registered as unaffiliated and aren't particularly swayed by partisan dismissals and hand-waving. That said, my recollection of the development and passage of the Affordable Care Act back in the day was that it was mostly good, excepting that it was subverted to support for-profit medicine instead of single-payer by the Republicans. It was a huge bill, but its development was not a trade secret. You may be remembering some personal TL;DR type reaction, but something being "too long, too hard" is hardly the same thing as a secret conspiracy. There's no apology sufficient for opaqueness in the process of domestic and civil legislation, and it would appear the far-right authoritarians don't recognize the public limits of their own competence and credibility. We demand an open process, credible objective outside experts: all aimed at non-profit social progress.

Comment: We cannot 'erase' the past. Covering it up is a form of erasure and risks further historical ignorance if not further revisionism. Better would be to apologise, learn from the past such that it is not repeated and uphold the actual detail existing legal treaties signed between crown and native groups. Once the current treaties are adhered to, then we could begin to look at forming a new relationship with native Canadians.

If anything this statue should be moved to a less prominent position and come with additional plaques describing Cornwallis' and settlers actions vis-a-vis the Mi'kmaq and other tribes.  This would serve as a reminder of the dangers of human pride, ignorance and evil.

But removing all traces of Canada's colonial past, good and bad,  is silly and counterproductive.

- Multiple Sclerosis

Comment: Page 114 of the 2006 NRC report:

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: The principle of voluntary government financing rests on the following premises: that the government is not the owner of the citizens’ income and, therefore, cannot hold a blank check on that income—that the nature of the proper governmental services must be constitutionally defined and delimited, leaving the government no power to enlarge the scope of its services at its own arbitrary discretion. 
-
Consequently, the principle of voluntary government financing regards the government as the servant, not the ruler, of the citizens—as an agent who must be paid for his services, not as a benefactor whose services are gratuitous, who dispenses something for nothing.

Comment: Apparently some people aren't clear as to what is going on.
-
Apparently the batteries are exactly the same. The only difference is that one was de-tuned and sold for $10,000 less than those that weren't de-tuned. But the batteries are the same. They are the same batteries in the same model of cars. That is why Tesla could remotely re-configure the software. The battery always had the capability that Tesla "hid." 
-
So is someone being ripped off for $10,000 because they are not getting a "bigger and better battery".....but the exact same battery that simply hasn't been manipulated and de-tuned via software manipulation? 
-
Is "computer software manipulation" a $10,000 cost? No, because the manipulation is apparently being done not to make the battery more efficient, but to make it less efficient.
-
Tesla isn't charging $10,000 more because they built a better battery. They are charging $10,000 less because because they manipulated the batteries performance to perform less.

Comment: I disagree with you regarding farmed fish and hatchery fish. Hatchery fish ARE wild fish. 
You folks have some other problem up there but it's not the fault of the hatchery fish because they are "wild" salmon. In Southeast, we have a number of hatcheries and we seem to be doing ok, recovering from the old days of Cannery fish traps and massive over fishing. Hatcheries release the fingerlings from the fertilized eggs of wild salmon. Then the fingerlings swim down the creek back into the ocean where their parents came from. Then they try to survive in the ocean until it's time to return back up the same creek they came from to spawn. Have you ever seen how tiny they are when released back to the ocean ?

Comment: A monument to their service is the most some of these vets can expect at this point.  If they or any of their surviving spouses availed themselves to the one-time monetary payout under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, signed into law by President Barack Obama, then any future claims against the United States had to be waived:

". . . the acceptance by an eligible person or surviving spouse, as applicable, of a payment under this section shall be final, and shall constitute a complete release of any claim against the United States by reason of any service described in subsection (d)."

In retrospect and after the passage of over 75 years, it may seem more than a little ironic that Filipinos of whatever persuasion back in 1942 should have staked their hopes upon anything promised by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt or the government of the United States.  A glance at the history of the Philippines after the Spanish-American War of 1898 should have given them pause.

An illegal alien is quite aware of their status, therefore when there’s a trip that requires proof of documentation beforehand, such students will know they don’t qualify and won’t register for the trip. Comment: Since before Confederation Canada has tried to balance the attractions of greater integration with the US with the need to foster strong and stable economic and political ties beyond the US embrace.

Clearly, maintaining and promoting this balance becomes harder and potentially more costly over the next decade but the need for that balance in order to protect Canada's independent capacity to preserve and promote its legitimate interests and values has never been greater.

To this end, there is a great need for Canada to foster trade and political links in East and South Asia, in Europe, Latin America, and Africa insofar as we don't unduly compromise or enduring interests and values in so doing.  Actually, this need is parallel to our similar need in dealing with the US.

In each case, Canada needs to remain calm and consistent in reaching out in all directions (and in building up domestic regional economic integration) but not being afraid to stand up to bullying if this is threatened.

Comment: My dearest, Mr Scott, you are omitting the implied word "humanely" before the word "execute." Of course we are going to execute the dog humanely! What sort of brutes do you imagine us to be? The dog is eventually going to die from an accident or humane execution anyway, and we are simply stepping up the more desirable option by a few short years. And we may very well be doing it a favor. Let's suppose the coach most responsible for the excruciating defeat in Kansas City returns home and finds his dog jumping around in glee at the occasion of his arrival. The coach, in his melancholy state of mind, thinks, "He's mocking me. My dog is mocking me!" Whereupon, he kicks the poor thing to death. We don't want that now, do we!?! Comment: Some good points here, with the shared goal of restoring healthy abundant salmon runs and providing needed food for So. Resident orcas, but the tone is a bit flippant about how to describe whale advocates and salmon restoration efforts. We are serious and well informed, but sometimes signs are needed to make a point, and those myriad restoration efforts have helped in ways hard to measure and shouldn't be discounted. Chemical contaminants are harmful of course and should be constrained and controlled to the extent possible, but mainly please know that the 2014 NOAA report has diluted the problem by spreading out the issues to the point that little action is prescribed to solve the main issue, which is lack of enough chinook salmon all year long. Fish farms don't grow healthy fish like mountain watersheds will. Mammal-eating orcas swim and eat in the same waters, but there are lots of seals and they're doing well. There are not lots of chinook for So. Residents however.

Comment: This letter addressed the first two of the three claims made in the 8/26 Letter to the Editor, that "Single-payer health care (aka socialized medicine or government-run health care) is rarely fast and is never free." Using credible sources, this letter made the case that those two claims were untrue. As for the unbearably sad story of Charlie Gard, who had an extremely rare inherited genetic disease - encephalomyopathic mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome (MDDS) - it was not an insurance company case worker who determined he was out of options. It was instead his own doctors and even Columbia University's Professor Michio Hirano, who initially proposed the unproven nucleoside therapy, who determined from a purely-scientific standpoint that nothing more could be done for him. The story of Charlie Gard is an incredibly heart-wrenching story, but it's a story about a tragedy, not how we pay for healthcare. The first two claims of the 8/26 letter have nothing to do with the third.

Comment: A classic case of "fit the facts to the desired message".

This hit piece works because of a simple yet knowingly-wrong assumption: that the incentives offered now -- in the very early years of EV development -- will continue unabated for the next decade and a half! 

No one in their right mind -- and certainly no one in policy -- thinks that's anywhere near being a reasonable assumption. EVs are starting up the curve. They may need a bit of assistance now because they don't yet benefit from a well-oiled (pun intended) supply chain, nor from economies of scale. But as they grow, costs will decline and incentives will as well, because EVs will be more competitive.

If you want an outcome badly enough -- because you have an axe to grind or an ideology to propel -- you can always choose assumptions that will get you there. Sadly, this seems to be one of those cases.

Comment: I once had Kaiser medical coverage in another state.   What I like most about it versus other medical insurance plans, was there was no paperwork.    You paid your copay when entering the door and that was it.  There was no subsequent billing with multiple columns showing amount charged,  allowed amount,  other insurance,  deductible, copay,  coinsurance, other amounts not covered,  and finally,  amount paid.   The only amount you paid was your premium and the copay per visit.  They handled everything else, very straight forward.  And there was no voluminous monthly statement of prescription charges showing how much was covered and how much was not covered and how close you were to your out of pocket maximum.

Comment: Medically assisted suicide is highly unethical in a country where one of the key problems with managing pain, disability and neurodegenerative disease stems from the lack of attention to basic treatments and undiagnosed malnutrition.  Malnutrition can be easily caused by malabsorption in the elderly.   Both spinal stenosis and multiple sclerosis can be related to vitamin deficiency -- particularly in one of the forms of vitamin B12.   The problem is that Canada doesn't test adequately for this, and one of the active forms of B12 isn't even available here, so effective treatment isn't even possible sometimes in Canada. 

There is a very large problem with neurodegenerative disease in Canada that can be substantially alleviated and sometimes eliminated in many people with appropriate testing and treatment of relatively common nutritional deficiencies.  People get very wound up about maintaining availability to use fentanyl.  Why not this far, far more?  It's cheap and safe.

Comment: The article misses a BIG issue; banks will not finance developments unless a certain percentage is pre-sold.  The threshold for financing is generally 65% pre-sales.  

If you're a developer who needs financing to build a highrise, do you think you'd prefer to have third party buyers making much of your profit by buying in advance and re-selling the purchase contract?  No.  The developer would rather get it built and sell the units at their market value once complete.  Because banks add this requirement, the developers have no choice but to look at it as a cost of financing.  

As to the suggestion that someone is avoiding property transfer tax by re-selling their right to buy, their is no merit to that.  No real estate has changed hands.  The only thing the pre-sale buyer sells is the right to buy, not the actual real estate.  

As to whether the ultimate sale attracts the 15% foreign buyer tax, that is a function of the residency of the ultimate buyer once the building is complete.

People have every right to protect themselves and their property.  Full registration of their weapons would not in any way change that.    NRA fed paranoia has been effective.

The arms race with the criminal world is a better argument.   If personal protection is your goal and you live in an area of the country with heavily armed criminals, then I can see where equal power would be wanted.  

Militias do NOT represent the majority, they are often NOT acting responsibly, they are threat to my public safety.     I have no trouble with continuing the ban on automatic weapons, designed or simulated.

Comment: Ignorant ? Read the paper as I have for the last 60 years. Every single year in Alaska there's more than one story of a pilot taking innocent passengers to their death.   In around 95 percent of the crashes pilot error is the cause. Over and over and over again it's stupid stuff---the pilot KNEW the weather was bad but headed out into it anyways , the pilot over loaded the airplane , the pilot didn't check his fuel , and the list goes on and on .  As has been said for years concerning Alaska and aviation---if you've lived any length of time at all in Alaska you knew or know of someone who died in a plane crash.  That say's it all concerning the cowboy attitude of Alaska pilots.  The only reason I comment on this subject is I hate to see all the innocent deaths .  When I pilot rolls the dice and he's the only one on board , that's how it goes. But when their stupidity and risk taking takes innocent lives---that's terrible. And it happens way too often in Alaska.

Comment: I'm quite serious.  I have a masters degree in theology, with a concentration in Church history.  Behind the question of "worthiness" of the celebrant of the Sacraments was an ecclesiology that believed that the Church was a "society of saints" more than a "school for sinners."  

This was a tension in the Church at that time.  Roman persecutions having ended, there were those, like the Egyptian hermits, who believed that the Church had gone "soft."  Only the hard-core believer, willing to offer his/her very life for the Lord was worthy of discipleship.    They lamented how "secular" Christian had become (Sound familiar?)  

The rigorists (i.e., Donatists) were often allied with the Arians, presenting Christ as the "super-human" who, by sheer effort and heroic self-denial, served as a witness for all Christians.  For that reason, Athanasius was happy to use St. Antony of the Desert, hero of the Egyptian monastics, as an ally against the Arians.

Comment: 1) That either of you are trying to equate killing a human with killing a lobster says all that needs to be said here.  Just crazy talk.

2) Using that hatchet is probably a faster and more certain way to kill the animal quickly.  Depending on a special device to electrocute it means you can never be sure the device will work correctly & raises the cost of killing dinner.  It also takes care of the squeamishness factor involved in actually killing something by making it seem "bloodless and humane".  It's not.  Sadly, I must go down the road of comparison here in spite of point (1).  An axe-man or a guillotine, or a firing squad were a quick and sure way to execute someone, but not bloodless.   So we went down the road of hanging, and electric chairs and gas chambers and now lethal injections to spare the feelings of the observers.  None of these methods are less painful for the condemned and are sometimes horrifically prolonged and agonizing.   Stick with the hatchet.

Comment: My reply was to, "Every group enforces norms or it ceases to be a cohesive group."  In the secular life of developed countries the "Who" who determined the norms ceased being a select group of elite following WWI.  That "Who" gradually expanded throughout the twentieth century to include women, people of color, etc.  In Western Europe, the monarchies along with the hereditary aristocracy, ceased to control the norms and disappeared or morphed. (Britain both morphed at home and disappeared in conflict/debate for some of its Empire, e.g. 26 counties of Ireland.)  

The "Who" who controls the norms became ever more inclusive in the developed world (civil rights movements here). Yet, the Church has retained the Divine right of Kingship accompanied by an aristocracy along with exclusion of women.  The loss of membership and differing views over the role of the laity displays the lack of cohesion.

The fissure is WHO interprets God's Word and Tradition and how and by whom norms are enforced.

Comment: Constitutional scholar. The only thing that got fudged in Roe was finding a plaintiff and keeping her because the normal pace of appeals would never let an abortion case get to SCOTUS..

Abortion comes under due process rights, according to Chief Justice Roberts in his confirmation hearing. Alito agreed.

Privacy is the relevant right, which comes under due process and equal protection.  It is not secrecy, it is the right to be left alone by the majority because the majority has no compelling interest in legislating on that matter. It applies to birth control, sodomy and prohibitions on gays marrying. While the Church would surely love to dump all of these things, it is not in the interest of the Republic to allow mob rule, even Catholic mob rule, in these matters.  As important is federal supremacy, which resides in the 14th Amendment.  Would you really repeal either? I certainly would not.  Note that these matters are both jurisdictional and have nothing to do with abortion per se.

Comment: That's not the foundational proposition of Natural Law.

Natural Law is grounded in the proposition that the universe is brought into existence, and sustained in it, wholly by the will and power of God. It asserts that Man, created male and female, in the image and likeness of God, has both a divine origin and a divine destiny. On this foundation rests the understanding of the human person as naturally possessed of inviolable dignity and inestimable worth, brought into existence for his or her own sake, with a purpose in God’s plan for the world He created.

It holds that we are bound by objective natural law, to which we are ordered for our flourishing and perfection, and for which God has given us the rational capacity to know, will and act.

Good and evil logically spring from this basic understanding.

Comment: In my opinion abortion should be legal and easy to administer at any stage if the mothers life is at risk because of the pregnancy and she chooses self preservation. This should be a decision between her, the father and the doctor.

Comment: I HATE that Trump was elected, but apparently you don't understand how the electoral college works. 

There are 538 electors from the 50 states. That number is based on the number of Representatives for each state (435 total based on state population) + 2 for the 2 senators for each state + 3 for DC. In most states, a electoral college voter CANNOT vote "against the state majority" (even if the "majority" is only 51% - which means essentially 49% of the state's votes "didn't count") without repercussions (in some states civil, in others criminal). That's how a candidate can win the popular vote and still lose the election - and the electoral college voters have very little choice (although the Constitution doesn't "bind" them to casting ALL votes the same as the popular majority for that state, the STATES DO).

No matter what your position is on the program it is laughable to suggest that anyone is "profiting" from the amount received.

Comment: My savings were just fine after 2008. It's called investing responsibly and intelligently. If you are very risk averse you can invest in GICs.  Zero risk and guaranteed returns. There are a large variety of GICs you can choose from. Some give guaranteed returns at flat rates (say 2%) and some are market oriented which guarantees a minimum return (say 0.25%) and a maximum return (Say 5%). But you never lose. 

If I die before I collect CPP the government keeps my money. I can bequeath my own investments to my family if this happens.  CPP is a defined benefit pension plan. This means that I don't see a single penny of the interest gained on the investment compared to the interest earned on my own investments. 

CPP is for those who don't understand investing and enjoy the government taking their money.

Comment: "While most states make similar exemptions for legislators, 12 states, including Oregon and Idaho, expect their lawmakers to comply with public records laws."

But not Washington.  And most states have this exemption for the same reason it exists in effect at the federal level.  We live in a constitutional republic, a *representative* form of government.  Our citizens have every right to participate in the electoral process to chose who represents us in making the law of the land.  

But they don't have every right to *every* detail of the sausage making that is the legislative process, nor should they IMO.  FOI laws unarguably protect the interests of the citizens and give them an important "check" against their government.  But there needs to be limits, or already stalemated legislatures would be even more incapable of negotiating solutions to problems. 

Voters have another check, every couple of years at election time.  In any case, this issue shouldn't be for the courts to decide.

Comment: Nope. Never touched weed. But, I did serve on the Parliamentary committee that held cross country hearings into drugs in the late 1980s. The almost uniform message we received from police and medical professionals was that alcohol was at least as dangerous to society as pot - except that it was legal and licensed; whereas, many casual users' lives could be "ruined" from having a criminal record.  My observations in "pot friendly" Netherlands in the last 15 years back that up. 

As for the refugee "drama (being) a cheap and temporary PR stunt" - I think not.. Canada has been a leading country accepting refugees since WW II. My best man, my sister-in-law and my business partner were all refugees admitted to Canada in 1949 to 1957. The two best employees I ever hired were East African Asian refugees. When I was In Parliament, a had a role (admittedly small) in our Indo-Chinese refugee programme in 1979. Canada has benefited greatly over the years from our refugee programmes.

Comment: To some extent I agree with your perspective - except that all the cranes downtown increase the population of Denver, which also proportionally increases the tax base for Denver and Colorado. In addition, there are hundreds of jobs associated with every one of those cranes, and each job holder is earning money that they spend and pay sales taxes, vehicle registration fees, and income taxes. The increased number of people buy more gas, more food, more of everything, and pay taxes with almost every purchase they make. The problem is not the increased number of people, it is the fact that governments, whether local, state, or federal, become self-serving bureaucracies that are more interested in growing their organization than in providing real service (DMV anybody?).

Comment: A lot of people seem to have missed Economics 101 and are failing to realize all actions have consequences.

Retrofitting older buildings to current Code to gain a small statistical increase in potential safety is often prohibitively expensive. There is no such thing as a free lunch, if the retrofit cost is higher than what current market rent will cover, which it will be, rents will have to be raised. If the raised rent would then be above market for the overall property, no one will rent there and the owners will simply sell the building for the land value, or switch it to non-residential purposes. 

Either way the current occupants will have to pay more or leave and that affordable housing will disappear, not to be replaced as building a new housing structure won't pencil out at current rates.

Comment: Average teaching salary in Ontario is 59 000 (Aug., 2017). It would be interesting to see the outcome if a teacher only worked for four hours. I invite you to walk into a classroom unprepared and spend the day with students. The day that begins at 9:00  "ends" at 3:20 (meaning the students leave). Teachers get 'prep' time that represents a small percentage of the time required to prepare fully (marking/planning/reports/IEPs). One break of 40 minutes (often 25, by the time you hand out pizza, milk, deal with lost shoes, nuts in a lunch, no lunch, student squabbles, etc.). The other break is 20 minutes (as duty is required for the other 20). During this 'break' teachers often coach sports in the gym or provide extra help, or deal with student problems (see above). Teachers put in additional hours before and after the 9 to 3:20 day. Sundays are often a full work  day for many of us. The last two weeks of August involve shopping for school and setting up the classroom.

Comment: As someone said, Trump will not be at the negotiating table. Skilled and experienced trade representatives will be there. 

As in any negotiation we will give some stuff up and they will give some stuff up. On the dairy supply issue, for example, we could agree to a gradual opening of our market with a time table to allow our producers to adapt. These are standard trade offs. In energy, no problem, You think you buy too much from us then let's reduce the NAFTA provisions that oblige us to reserve a percentage of our production for your market freeing us to sell elsewhere. Softwood lumber, no need for a tax or levy, we will raise our prices to match your market prices by raising our stump fees. Now watch your housing industry growth slow in accordance. And on and on....

Trump has set the table for a re-negotiation but from here on in he's becoming more and more of a side show. His negotiators know the numbers and they know you can't bully your way into a market. It takes concessions.

Comment: The grand fib of lessons learned has long been debunked. Even Jack Granastein, who tends to be pretty conservative in his historical interpretations, refers to Dieppe as a "colossal blunder".

"Back in England, nothing mattered except that reputations be saved. The Dieppe raid became a model of how to spin the facts, as historian Timothy Balzer has conclusively demonstrated. Mountbatten’s expert public relations team turned out to be better at preparing their media lines for failure than his planners had been at drawing up the strategy for operational success. Combined Operations Headquarters instantly claimed that the raid had been a great achievement and learning experience, and they held to that line even after the casualty lists became public." http://www.canadashistory.ca/Explore/Military-War/Dieppe-A-Colossal-Blunder

Comment: Most intelligent drones (read: most DJI products, and several other "big name brands") have altimeters/barometers in them, and the telemetry is transmitted back to the controller. So either a screen on the remote, or on a connected phone/tablet display a whole array of data to the pilot such as:
- Distance from pilot
- Altitude
- Altitude AGL (Above Ground Level)
- Speeds
- GPS Location (with map)
- Safety alerts, airspace warnings etc
- Feed from the main camera
- Sensor information, signal strength etc

Not to mention a plethora of safety features built in, to help the pilot with (or in some cases attempt to enforce) safe flying, and avoiding restricted airspace.

Comment: What you said about hearsay in your other comment is certainly correct, as are most of the comments on here expressing support for UBC's decision to reinstate the invitation, as a matter of principle, on the facts of this situation.   But you go too far when you say a University should leave the issue of sexual assault entirely to the police and the courts.   It can take years for an assault charge to be investigated and prosecuted criminally.   Where the evidence is sufficient, the university has a duty to other students to ensure their safety by dealing with the alleged assailant, to the point of expulsion if necessary.    While providing due process, of course, which doesn't mean accepting all allegations credulously.
